frame.name: Perception_experience
frame.definition:
<def-root>This frame contains perception words whose Perceivers have perceptual experiences that they do not necessarily intend to. For this reason we call the Perceiver role <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>. Comparing the Perception_experience frame to the Perception_active frame, we note that for some modalities there are different lexical items in each frame. For instance, whereas Perception_experience has <m>see</m>, Perception_active has <m>look at</m>. For other sense modalities, we find the same lexical items in both frames. To illustrate, consider the verb <m>smell</m> where <m>I smell something rotten</m> exemplifies its Perception_experience use and <m>Smell this to see if it's fresh</m> exemplifies its Perception_active sense. This frame also includes words which are not specific to any sense modality, including <m>detect, perceive, perception, sense</m>. <ex></ex> <ex>Abashed, realising that <fex name="Perceiver_passive">he</fex> had <t>overheard</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">her conversation with Victoria</fex>, Sheeley didn't try to make excuses.</ex>
<ex><fex name="Perceiver_passive">She</fex> <t>smelled</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">the wine</fex> <fex name="State">on Paul's breath</fex>, and bade him to sit down.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Perceiver_passive
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE is the being who has a perceptual experience, not necessarily on purpose. It is typically expressed as an External Argument.
<ex><fex name="Perceiver_passive">The waiter</fex> <t>smelled</t> something foul in the kitchen.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Phenomenon
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE is the entity or phenomenon that the perceiver experiences with his or her senses. It is typically expressed as Object with verbs.
<ex>The waiter <t>smelled</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">something foul</fex> in the kitchen.</ex>
<ex>I <t>saw</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">the baker</fex> <fex name="Phenomenon">prepare his special peanut butter pie</fex></ex>.</def-root>

FE.name: Body_part
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the location on the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>'s body where the perceptual experience takes place. It is typically expressed in a PP. <ex>Marlow <t>felt</t> something cold and hard <fex name="Body_part">against the back of his neck</fex>.</ex> This Frame Element occurs less frequently than others, because many target words imply that a particular part of the body is involved (e.g. smelling must be done with the nose). However, the verb <ment>feel</ment> does take this Frame Element, because touch is not localized on the body the same way other modalities are. <fen>Body_part</fen> may be expressed in other modalities when it adds specificity to what is implied by the target word in question. <ex>I <t>heard</t> a ringing <fex name="Body_part">in my right ear</fex>. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Location_of_protagonist
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Location_of_protagonist</fen> during the perceptual experience. It is typically expressed in a <ment>from</ment>-PP. <ex>The witnesses <t>saw</t> the robbery <fex name="Location_of_protagonist">from the their car</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition: <def-root>This frame element is used for all path-like expressions, except those indicating the location of the perceiver (see above), that describe how the perceiver's attention is directed during the act of perception. <ex>The detective could easily <t>see</t> <fex name="Direction">into the house</fex>.</ex> <ex>The detective <t>heard</t> their conversation <fex name="Direction">through the wall</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Depictive
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>State</fen> indicates predicate expressions that apply to the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>, providing some information about the state it is in while the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> experiences it.
<ex>The detective <t>saw</t> the suspect <fex name="Depictive">fleeing</fex>.</ex> <ex>Pat <t>saw</t> Kim <fex name="Depictive">naked</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: State
FE.definition:
<def-root><fen>State</fen> is the location, activity, or other characteristic of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<ex>I <t>saw</t> the baker <fex name="State">baking his special peanut butter pie</fex></ex>.
<ex>I <t>overheard</t> the cat <fex name="State">in the cupboard</fex></ex>.
<ex>I <t>heard</t> fear <fex name="State">in his voice</fex></ex>.</def-root>

FE.name: Manner
FE.definition:
<def-root>Manner expressions may be of lexicographic interest if they describe properties of perception as such: <ment>clearly</ment>, <ment>loudly</ment>, etc.
<ex>Pat <t>heard</t> the shot <fex name="Manner">clearly</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Degree</fen> indicates the degree to which the Perception is experienced.
<ex>A nightmare creature, <fex name="Degr">barely</fex> <t>perceived</t> in the swirling dense smoke, was beating at the flames coming from its own body.</ex> <ex>Older people <t>perceive</t> <fex name="Degr">less well</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Means
FE.definition:
<def-root>The action whereby the Perceiver perceives.
<ex>He <t>saw</t> it <fex name="Mns">by looking out the window</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> or the <fen>Body_part</fen> perceives the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>. </def-root>

FE.name: Duration
FE.definition: <def-root>Duration denotes the length of time from the beginning of a continuous situation (the one denoted by the target) to its end. </def-root>

FE.name: Contrastive_context
FE.definition:
<def-root>An element of the discourse that serves to contextualize the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>, with which it is directly related (i.e. filling a frame-element role of the Phenomenon or vice-versa). It contrasts with other contextually relevant elements that potentially (but do not actually) fill the same role.
<ex>Such a difference in note-taking accuracy can also be <t>seen</t> <fex name="Contrastive_context">for second-year pupils</fex> .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Concessive
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE signifies that the state-of-affairs expressed by the main clause (containing the target) occurs or holds, and something other than that state-of-affairs would be expected given the state-of-affairs in the concessive clause.</def-root>

FE.name: Circumstances
FE.definition: <def-root>A situation which pertains during the event. This frame element is primarily used to highlight the event denoted by the target against a (potentially partially) causal or concessive background state-of-affairs.</def-root>

FE.name: Frequency
FE.definition: <def-root>An expression of how often the event occurs.</def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition: <def-root>The general location within which the act of perception takes place.</def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Ground</fen> is the perceptual background against which the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is experienced (or not experienced) by the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>. It can be distinguished from locative postnominal modifiers of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> in negative contexts. <ex>Pat didn't <t>see</t> Kim <fex name="Ground">behind the bar</fex>.</ex> In this example, it is implied that Pat looked behind the bar and did not find Kim there. </def-root>

FE.name: Obscuring_medium
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Obscuring_medium</fen> is the medium through which the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> makes itself perceivable to the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>. This is similar to the <fen>Direction</fen>, but occurs in the opposite direction and implies a movement of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<ex>My mother <t>heard</t> the scream <fex name="Obscuring_medium">through the attic window</fex></ex>.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: detect.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: discern (something intangible or barely perceptible)

lexUnit.name: feel.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: be aware of (something happening) through physical sensation

lexUnit.name: hear.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: perceive (a sound) with the ear

lexUnit.name: perceive.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: become aware or conscious of

lexUnit.name: perception.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the process of becoming aware of something through the senses.

lexUnit.name: sense.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: perceive by a sense or senses' be vaguely or indefinably aware of

lexUnit.name: smell.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: perceive or detect the odour of something by the faculty of smell.

lexUnit.name: taste.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: perceive or experience the flavour of.

lexUnit.name: experience.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an event or occurrence which leaves an impression on one.

lexUnit.name: witness.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to see an event occur, especially as a bystander.

lexUnit.name: experience.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to undergo an experience or event
